name: asimina-triloba-overleese
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern Canada to Eastern United States
distribution: south to North Carolina and Florida.
wildlife-value: Its flowers are pollinated by flies and beetles. Its fleshy fruits are eaten by songbirds, wild turkeys, squirrels, raccoons, opossums, black bears, and foxes. Pawpaws are larval host plants for the Zebra Swallowtail (Eurytides marcellus). The adult butterflies lay eggs in the north during two flights between April and August and in the south between March and December.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: Resistant to fire. Moderately resistant to deer damage. Heat tolerant.
edibility: Fruits are edible and large. Fewer seed than most varieties. Flesh yellow. Flavor excellent. Ripe beginning of October.
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Large yellow fruit with yellow flesh and good flavor. Fewer seeds than most cultivars. October ripening.
flower-description: The burgundy flowers bloom in spring but are not showy. They are purplish brown with 6 petals and are 1 to 1.5 inches in diameter. They have a foul odor as they are pollinated by flies.
leaf-description: Alternate, simple, obovate to oblong 6-12 inches long 2-3 inches wide with a green pepper odor when crushed. The leaves are in two ranks and hang pendulously from the stem. The leaf underside is pale and glaucous.
bark-description: Smooth, brown splotched with wart-like lenticels. Becomes fissured and scaly with age.
stem-description: Buds are pubescent with no scales. Young buds and stems are cinnamon brown.
poison-symptoms: Seeds and unripe fruit may cause stomach and intestinal pain. Be sure fruit is ripe before ingesting. Skin irritation from handling fruit.
uses: Early Americans made yellow dye from pulp of the ripened fruit.
